sets.name: Sun Wallbreaker
sets.description:
Charizard makes its name as one of the premier wallbreakers on sun teams with its ability to carve through most of the metagame with its obscene power, although Charizard is only as good as sun teams are, which can be an inconsistent team style at times. Charizard remains a solid pick for sun teams despite facing competition from Solar Power Heliolisk, which has a higher Speed tier and better defensive typing that grants a Ghost immunity and Flying resistance, as a wallbreaker. Solar Beam makes it so bulky Water-types such as Gastrodon and Milotic, as well as bulky Rock-types such as Diancie, cannot wall Charizard safely in sun. Scorching Sands hits Fire-types such as Volcanion, Chandelure, and Incineroar, as well as Dragalge, which could give its team grievances. Fire Blast provides a strong Fire-type STAB attack outside of sun, while Roost lets Charizard heal against Grass-types such as Vileplume and Roserade and Pokemon attempting to stall out sun turns with Protect, such as Umbreon, Suicune, and Chandelure. Heavy-Duty Boots improves Charizard's longevity, although Choice Specs is an option to increase its wallbreaking capabilities and secure KOs, such as OHKOing defensive Togekiss, at the cost of being less consistent due to the crippling Stealth Rock weakness and being Choice-locked.

Charizard is only seen on sun teams, so its partners should reflect this. Torkoal sets sun and empowers Charizard, Chlorophyll sweepers such as Shitry can capitalize on Charizard's wallbreaking and ability to handle Togekiss and opposing Fire-types, and wallbreakers such as Darmanitan and Entei provide additional offensive pressure as well as pivot support and strong priority. Xatu makes a solid partner for Charizard thanks to its ability to block entry hazards with Magic Bounce with Teleport, for Charizard to take advantage of should especially if it opts to run Choice Specs. Klefki makes an excellent manual sun setter and provides Spikes to wear down bulky Water-types. Other partners include Choice Scarf Flygon, which can safely bring in Charizard with U-turn and provide a valuable Rock resistance, and Choice Scarf Gardevoir, which provides Healing Wish and can cripple Pokemon like Snorlax with Trick or bring Charizard in safely with Teleport.

Vileplume.overview: The following analysis is outdated and is currently being revamped. Information contained in the analysis may be misinformative in regards to the current SS RU metagame.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description: Vileplume's reliable bulk and good defensive typing allow it to act as a switch-in to common pivots in RU such as Zarude and Mienshao, while its ability Effect Spore lets it pressure physical attackers such as Cobalion and Sharpedo. Unfortunately, Vileplume can get worn down quickly and is often forced to use its recovery to remain healthy, which gives openings to Pokemon it invites in like Toxtricity and common Flying-types such as Noivern and Crobat. Strength Sap is Vileplumeâ€™s main recovery move and allows it to lower the Attack stat of an opposing physical attacker. Corrosive Gas is used to remove important items such as Leftovers, Heavy-Duty Boots, and Choice items from Pokemon such as Cobalion, Crobat, and Toxtricity. Alternatively, Sleep Powder can be used to put common switch-ins such as Crobat and Noivern to sleep, generating free turns for itself and its teammates. An alternative EV spread of 252 HP / 144 Def / 112 SpD can be used to avoid a 4HKO from Xurkitree's Thunderbolt. Vileplume is best suited for balance teams that need a check for prominent physical attackers such as Zarude and Mienshao. Due to Vileplume's weakness to Fire-types, bulky Water-types such as Suicune and Milotic can be great teammates. In return, Vileplume can handle offensive Electric-types such as Xurkitree and Raikou. Since Vileplume often invites in Flying-types like Crobat and Tornadus, checks to these Pokemon such as Xurkitree and Raikou are good partners. Registeel and Steelix also make great teammates for Vileplume, since they are able to check offensive Psychic-types such as Gardevoir and Necrozma. Since Vileplume often switches into pivots, taking damage from entry hazards can quickly wear it down and limit its defensive capabilities, so entry hazard removal from Togekiss or Crobat is important.

Cloyster.overview: The following analysis is outdated and is currently being revamped. Information contained in the analysis may be misinformative in regards to the current SS RU metagame.

sets.name: Shell Smash Sweeper
sets.description:
Shell Smash Cloyster's ability to potentially break past its checks through flinches make it a threatening setup sweeper. It also takes advantage of teams relying on Seismitoad and Gastrodon as their bulky Water-type, as neither is a suitable Cloyster check. Rock Blast hits Water-types such as Milotic and Suicune neutrally, helping Cloyster beat them with flinches. It also hits Volcanion and can be used against other Fire-types like Incineroar and Chandelure. Hydro Pump is the preferred last move due to its greater damage against Steel-types such as Metagross, Cobalion, and Steelix. Liquidation can be used instead to OHKO Diancie and potentially 2HKO Registeel after Spikes damage while also giving Cloyster a more reliable Water-type STAB move. However, it makes Cloyster more reliant on breaking past the aforementioned Steel-types with flinches. King's Rock gives Cloyster's Icicle Spear and Rock Blast an effective 41% flinch chance. A Naive or Jolly nature should be used, as they allow +2 Cloyster to outrun Choice Scarf Mienshao. Explosion can be used to take down Water-types such as Milotic and Suicune for a teammate. Focus Sash can be used to almost guarantee setup, but this requires solid entry hazard removal, and Cloyster loses out on the ability to break past its checks with flinches. Life Orb is another item option that allows Cloyster to KO notable threats such as Cobalion, Galarian Weezing, Metagross, and Doublade at +2 without prior residual damage. Spikes allows Cloyster, which beats most Defoggers, to give value to its team in a matchup where it doesn't do much else. However, Spikes also forces Cloyster to ditch its Water-type STAB moves, which worsens its matchup against Steel-types significantly.

Cloyster's natural physical bulk is impressive even without investment and gives it some notable setup opportunities against Pokemon such as Darmanitan, Crobat lacking Taunt, and Mimikyu. Cloyster is potentially capable of breaking past its defensive answers with flinches, but this requires a fair bit of luck. Bulky Water- and Steel-types can halt Cloyster barring an ill-timed flinch, so efforts should be put into wearing these Pokemon down. Most of the tier's bulky Steel-types will get worn down by Spikes; offensive Metagross, Cobalion, and Doublade will be in KO range of +2 Hydro Pump after switching in with three layers of Spikes, while Liquidation variants will be able to reliably 2HKO Registeel after two layers. Therefore, Spikes setters like Klefki and Roserade are good teammates. Cloyster's ability to take advantage of Spikes and cause its targets to flinch makes it a great choice for hyper offense teams, as it can be a devastating wincon or a supportive wallbreaker for another sweeping teammate such as Necrozma, Mimikyu, or Polteageist. Cloyster is also capable of sweeping on standard offensive and bulky offensive teams. Teams utilizing Cloyster in this regard should attempt to wear down bulky Water- and Steel-types. Knock Off from the likes of Incineroar, Reuniclus, and Obstagoon can remove Leftovers from Pokemon like Registeel and Suicune, making it easier for Cloyster to break through them. Pivoting teammates, such as Mienshao, Incineroar, and Crobat, can get Cloyster into battle safely. Toxic from Diancie and Salazzle can help wear down Water-types to let Cloyster go wild late-game.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description:
Alolan Marowak is a fearsome wallbreaker in RU that is also able to soft check many dangerous threats, such as Roserade, Xurkitree, Toxtricity, and Cobalion, due to its Lightning Rod ability and typing. Unfortunately, Alolan Marowak struggles to find wallbreaking opportunities, and it is also revenge killed easily due to its low Speed stat, vulnerability to Stealth Rock, weaknesses to common types, and mediocre bulk. Swords Dance lets Alolan Marowak break through every wall in RU after one boost. Alternatively, Flame Charge alongside a Jolly nature can be used to prevent it from being outsped and revenge killed by Pokemon such as Flame Orb Heracross, Chandelure, and Nidoqueen after one boost. However, even after one boost, it is still slower than many common threats like Obstagoon, Flygon, and Noivern. Earthquake 2HKOes Incineroar after Intimidate and provides a stronger hit against Volcanion and Diancie. However, Low Kick gets an OHKO on Obstagoon, hits Snorlax much harder, and deals more damage than Fire Punch to some bulky Steel-types, such as Registeel and Steelix.

An entry hazard remover like Noivern, Crobat, or Togekiss is crucial to pair with Alolan Marowak, as every entry hazard, especially Stealth Rock, limits its ability to switch into the mentioned threats. Offensive pivots like Noivern, Xurkitree, and Raikou support Alolan Marowak with free switches into defensive Pokemon it defeats easily, such as Registeel, Assault Vest Reuniclus, and Bronzong. Roserade checks Water-types, Golisopod checks Ground-types like Flygon, and both provide Spikes support. In general, Alolan Marowak appreciates bulky teammates like Togekiss, Celebi, and Steelix, since it's easily revenge killed by many Pokemon due to its low base Speed and common weaknesses. Wish support from Togekiss and Sylveon helps Alolan Marowak to stay healthy. Powerful late-game cleaners like Choice Scarf Heracross and Choice Scarf Xurkitree appreciate Alolan Marowak's wallbreaking capabilities.

sets.name: Misty Terrain
sets.description:
Misty Explosion and Memento fulfill very similar roles on this set - preserving momentum. Misty Explosion isn't blocked by Clear Body and Taunt and is able to deal not-insignificant damage to many targets like Cobalion, Togekiss, and Gastrodon, while Memento helps sweepers that are often paired with Galarian Weezing set up uncontested. Taunt blocks Defog and setup attempts from Pokemon like Togekiss and Doublade, which could prevent Galarian Weezing's teammates from sweeping. To ensure Misty Terrain is active, the last moveslot is used for it, which helps against faster Defoggers like Crobat and Volcanion after using Taunt on them. Fire Blast is an alternative last move to chip Steel-types like Metagross and Doublade.

Galarian Weezing's Misty Terrain blocks status for grounded Pokemon, so it fits great on setup spam hyper offense. Dual screen setters like Ribombee and Grimmsnarl are great teammates, as Ribombee also provides Sticky Web, while Grimmsnarl sets up screens with priority. Sweepers that make Misty Terain worthwhile include Slurpuff, Polteageist, Necrozma, and Cloyster, to name a few. Cloyster and Necrozma are particularly good teammates because they set up on Pokemon that Galarian Weezing invites in, such as Ground-types and Steel-, and Psychic-types, respectively. Other sweepers like Weakness Policy Metagross and Incineroar are able to use the weaknesses they share with Galarian Weezing to get boosts against common Pokemon like Flygon and Cobalion. However, due to Misty Terrain halving Dragon-type attacks' power, sweepers like Regidrago and Tyrantrum are hard to fit on teams with Galarian Weezing.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
Galarian Weezing's immense physical bulk and good defensive typing make it a good check to common threats such as Mimikyu, Golisopod, and Heracross. Neutralizing Gas gives it a unique advantage in negating abilites like Heracross's and Obstagoon's Guts, Reuniclus's Regenerator, Darmanitan's Sheer Force, and Cloyster's Skill Link. Galarian Weezing's mediocre special bulk, lack of consistent recovery, and general passivity make it harder to support and fit on teams than its Fairy-type competition of Togekiss and Diancie. Sludge Bomb is preferred over Sludge Wave for its higher chance of poisoning. Galarian Weezing can be used as a Defogger, though it dislikes Stealth Rock setters such as Necrozma, Cobalion, and Nidoqueen. Toxic Spikes can be useful for crippling Pokemon such as Gastrodon, Milotic, and Diancie, but it's matchup-dependent due to the prevalence of Heavy-Duty Boots and the large amount of viable Poison- and Steel-types such as Roserade, Toxtricity, Cobalion, and Metagross. Pain Split gives Galarian Weezing a form of recovery, albeit an unreliable one. Will-O-Wisp burns threats such as Cobalion, Mimikyu, and Cloyster. Corrosive Gas can be used to remove items from the likes of Roserade, Registeel, and Chandelure. Rest is a viable option on stall teams, but stall is a rather unreliable playstyle as a whole. Black Sludge is preferred to give Galarian Weezing more survivability. Rocky Helmet can be used to force more damage onto the likes of Golisopod and Heracross, but should only be used with dedicated Wish support. Heavy-Duty Boots can be used to mitigate entry hazard damage, but it has the same recovery issue as Rocky Helmet.

Galarian Weezing can be used on balance and stall teams that cover for it sapping momentum and appreciate it checking threats in Heracross, Regidrago, and Obstagoon. Pokemon such as Registeel, Porygon2, and Assault Vest Reuniclus can help against specially offensive threats to Galarian Weezing such as Salazzle, Raikou, Necrozma, and Toxtricity. Registeel and Porygon2 also appreciate Galarian Weezing switching into threatening Fighting-types. Options such as Quagsire, Suicune, and Volcanion are capable of taking on offensive Steel-types such as Cobalion and Metagross. Volcanion is also a capable Defogger, freeing up Galarian Weezing to run other moves, most notably Pain Split. Every Electric-type in the tier forces Galarian Weezing out, leading to free uses of Volt Switch. Gastrodon and Steelix are viable Ground-type partners as a result. Wish passing from the likes of Umbreon is useful and practically mandatory on stall, as Galarian Weezing lacks reliable recovery. Variants running Toxic Spikes can be supported by bulky Calm Mind sweepers like Suicune. Threats to Poison-types such as Necrozma, Gardevoir, and Alolan Marowak are important on such teams.

Starmie.overview: Starmie is a great defensive spinner that matches up well into the common entry hazard setters of the tier and can pivot. Starmie's phenomenal Speed tier and ability to force foes out with its great super effective coverage also make it an exceptional wallbreaker and allow it to take advantage of Analytic. Its bulk uninvested is unimpressive however, limiting opportunities for offensive sets to come into battle or forcing Starmie to click Recover instead of attacking. Specially defensive walls like Registeel, Assault Vest Reuniclus, and Porygon2 also prove difficult to beat without Analytic boosts. Starmie has to fear being picked off by First Impression from Golisopod and other naturally fast Pokemon like Raikou and Noivern that can take advantage of Starmie's frailty and force it out. Additionally, Analytic can be rendered useless by the opponent positioning themselves correctly.
Starmie.comments:
Other Options

Starmie can run specific coverage moves to hit certain targets. Thunderbolt is an option that hits Water-types like Volcanion and revenge kills Golisopod, although it misses out on Gastrodon, which is only threatened by Grass Knot. Psychic provides ample neutral coverage and eases prediction but has few relevant targets. Life Orb Starmie can run Protect to block First Impression from Golisopod and threaten it with Thunderbolt. Choice Specs allows Starmie to garner crucial OHKOs, such as on Cobalion with Hydro Pump after Stealth Rock and Decidueye, Dhelmise, and Vileplume with Analytic-boosted Ice Beam, but being Choice-locked prevents it from taking advantage of its coverage.

Checks and Counters

Faster Threats and Priority: Due to Starmie's lack of bulk on offensive sets, Golisopod can pick it off with First Impression, and Toxicroak can OHKO with boosted Sucker Punch. Starmie is also susceptible to faster Pokemon like Raikou and Noivern, which force it out.

Specially Defensive Walls: Assault Vest Reuniclus, Snorlax, and Umbreon can take any of Starmie's moves and 2HKO in return, with Umbreon being able to also heal off before so.

Bulky Water-types: Bulky Water-types such as Milotic, Volcanion, and Suicune wall defensive Starmie, but Starmie can get momentum as they switch in by using Teleport. Offensive Starmie can still be walled by bulky Water-types; however, they cannot freely switch in due to Analytic-boosted super effective coverage.

sets.name: Rapid Spin
sets.description:
Starmie is a consistent entry hazard removal option due to its favourable matchups against common hazard setters such as Cobalion and Steelix giving it opportunity to pivot or use Rapid Spin. Teleport allows Starmie to take advantage of these entry hazard setters and get teammates in safely. Toxic is an option that cripples bulky Water-types such as Volcanion, Milotic, and Gatstrodon, although Roserade and Toxicroak can take advantage of it. Psyshock with 64 Special Attack EVs is an option to OHKO Roserade.

Starmie can fit on any archetype but is preferred on entry hazard and offensive teams, assisting teammates like Darmanitan and Lucario. Wallbreakers such as Toxtricity and Chandelure benefit from Teleport giving them a free switch and allowing them to threaten Starmie's checks such as Vileplume, threatening certain sets with an OHKO. Starmie's Rapid Spin and Teleport also benefit Choice Scarf Darmanitan and Calm Mind Raikou. Noivern and Crobat resist First Impression from Golisopod and stop Grass-types such as Celebi from freely setting up on Starmie; in return, Starmie's Rapid Spin allows Crobat and Noivern to run another move instead of Defog.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description:
Starmie's expansive offensive movepool allows it to act as a powerful wallbreaker that can use super effective coverage and Analytic to break past usual Water-type checks. Hydro Pump is an option over Surf to deal more damage to neutral targets, although its accuracy is a concern due to Starmie's below-average bulk. Ice Beam hits Grass- and Dragon-types such as Celebi, Roserade, and Noivern. Grass Knot nails bulky Water-types such as Milotic, Gastrodon, and Suicune. Starmie can take advantage of forced switches to regain health with Recover and continue firing off hits. Rapid Spin is an option if a team desperately needs entry hazard removal, and it has the added benefit of potentially making Starmie a threatening cleaner with the Speed boost.

Entry hazard setters such as Roserade, Necrozma, and Klefki can help Starmie pressure balance cores more easily. Pivots like Talonflame and Incineroar can bring it into Pokemon it threatens such as Diancie and Galarian Weezing. Other wallbreakers like Darmanitan and Calm Mind Raikou can form cores with Starmie to break down each other's checks in bulky Water- and Grass-types. Pangoro, Obstagoon, and Heracross deal with specially defensive walls like Umbreon and Porygon2. Finally, cleaners such as Sharpedo and Mimikyu take advantage of Starmie's wallbreaking to sweep.

sets.name: Revenge Killer
sets.description:
Ditto is a reliable revenge killer with good offensive matchups, since it's able to revenge kill Pokemon like Swords Dance Cobalion and Shell Smash Cloyster. It also has a good stall matchup because it can infinitely replenish PP and copy utility moves. Ditto's EVs just maximize its physical bulk and minimize Speed in case of the rare Ditto mirror matchup, while the Impish nature and 4 Speed IVs with a Choice Scarf allow it to outspeed Galarian Weezing, which can block Imposter by activating Neutralizing Gas. An alternative spread with 0 Speed IVs and a Relaxed nature maximizes Ditto's chances of winning mirror matchups.

Ditto can fit on a team mainly looking for a revenge killer to deal with a range of threats that cannot be walled by a single Pokemon and could break through the team. Thus, it's a solid pick with a defensive backbone. In return, defensive teammates can switch into offensive foes for it. Ditto can also fit on offensive teams that have very little defensive backbone, revenge killing threats that could run through the team and patching up the stall matchup. Ditto in turn appreciates offensive breakers such as Toxtricity and Heracross helping its shaky matchup against balance teams. It also needs teammates that can beat Substitute users like Suicune and Volcanion; countermeasures to these Pokemon include Infiltrator Pokemon such as Toxic Crobat and Noivern. Entry hazard removers like Togekiss can also be helpful for Ditto to reliably switch into threats. Cleric support from Pokemon like Umbreon and Sylveon prevents Toxic from stopping Ditto against stall teams. Finally, Knock Off absorbers like Bewear and Cobalion can be vital, as Ditto losing its Choice Scarf means it will be unable to revenge kill offensive threats.

sets.name: Rain Sweeper
sets.description:
Kabutops is a niche but potent rain attacker with access to Swords Dance that can hit most rain checks like Gastrodon neutrally. Liquidation is stronger than Waterfall, but Waterfall can give unexpected openings through flinches. Superpower lets Kabutops break past Gastrodon if it is chipped, while Aqua Jet can clean even if rain runs out. Protect can be used to prevent First Impression.

Kabutops should always be run with Politoed on dedicated rain teams. Other rain sweepers such as Kingdra, Nasty Plot Tornadus, and Ludicolo can work in tandem with Kabutops to wear down the opposing team's defensive structure. Checks to opposing Gastrodon, such as Tornadus and Ludicolo, are necessary, as Kabutops is completely walled by them. Other Pokemon that fit on rain teams like Klefki, Toxicroak, and Raikou also pair well with Kabutops.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description:
Dragon Dance allows Aerodactyl to function as a dangerous setup sweeper. One boost from Dragon Dance lets Aerodactyl OHKO threats like Cobalion while being faster than most Choice Scarf users, including Flygon and Darmanitan. Earthquake hits Steel-types like Steelix, Stakataka, and Metagross that resist both STAB moves. Life Orb is preferred, but Heavy-Duty Boots does grant Aerodactyl Stealth Rock immunity and lacks Life Orb's recoil, which makes setting up easier. An Adamant nature lets Aerodactyl hit harder, while a Jolly nature lets it outspeed Noivern unboosted. Unnerve prevents threats like Cobalion from using their Shuca Berry and eating up an Earthquake.

Bulky Water-types like Milotic, Suicune, and Gastrodon eat up Aerodactyl's moves and check it, so teammates like Celebi, Roserade, and Toxtricity are appreciated. Celebi serves as a Scald switch-in that can pivot out on a Togekiss or Noivern switch-in for Aerodactyl. Roserade provides Spikes support to wear down said Water-types as well as a super effective STAB Leaf Storm. Despite Earthquake being able to hit them, Steel-types like Doublade, Steelix, and Registeel can be problematic. Teammates like Incineroar, Milotic, and Heracross handle them with minimal fuss. A partner like Obstagoon or Choice Specs Gardevoir can wear down Steel-types to put them in OHKO range of Aerodactyl's attacks. Teammates like Dhelmise and Registeel that appreciate Aerodactyl pressuring threats like Noivern, Chandelure, and Fighting-types work as partners. Dhelmise is notable because it provides Rapid Spin support for Aerodactyl using Life Orb. Other notable entry hazard control teammates include Starmie and Volcanion to check threats like Bronzong.

sets.name: 3 Attacks + Roost
sets.description: Aerodactyl's natural Speed and Attack stats also make it a decent choice for an anti-offense Pokemon, outspeeding common threats like Noivern and Raikou. Earthquake guarantees OHKOs on Electric-types like Xurkitree and Toxtricity while guaranteeing 2HKOs on Steel-types like Metagross and Stakataka. Roost gives Aerodactyl reliable recovery to make up for Life Orb recoil and potential Stealth Rock chip if it's not carrying Heavy-Duty Boots. Teammates like Galarian Weezing and Volcanion can provide Defog support while also checking threats like Choice Scarf Heracross and bulkier Steel-types, respectively. Dhelmise, Roserade, and Xurkitree can deal with bulky Water-types like Milotic, Suicune, and Gastrodon that give Aerodactyl a hard time. Dhelmise provides Rapid Spin support, while Roserade provides Spikes support to further wear down Aerodactyl's checks. Teammates like Celebi and Cobalion that can bring in Aerodactyl safely to beat Togekiss and Chandelure, respectively, are appreciated. Choice Scarf users like Xurkitree, Darmanitan, and the aforementioned Heracross OHKO Aerodactyl. Therefore, teammates like Assault Vest Reuniclus, Milotic, and Galarian Weezing are useful to check these threats.

sets.name: Curselax
sets.description:
Snorlax's overall bulk and access to Curse enable it to check Fire- and Electric-types such as Chandelure, Darmanitan, and Raikou. However, Snorlax's typing leaves it with no resistances, making it unable to switch into powerful Pokemon such as Choice Specs Toxtricity and Indeedee-M. Curse enables Snorlax to have immense sweeping potential while also letting it threaten its checks. Body Slam inflicts paralysis, making it easier for Snorlax to get boosts from Curse while helping its teammates by slowing down faster threats. Earthquake provides great coverage against Normal-resistant and -immune Pokemon like Cobalion and Alolan Marowak. Rest is Snorlax's main recovery move while also being able to remove status effects. Thick Fat enables Snorlax to reliably switch into Fire-types like Chandelure and Volcanion. 12 HP EVs slightly increase recovery from Leftovers. Snorlax can opt for a spread of 12 HP / 116 Atk / 204 Def / 176 SpD to OHKO Cobalion with Earthquake after a Curse and a Defense drop from Close Combat and evade a 3HKO from Xurkitree's Thunderbolt and Volcanion's Steam Eruption. Alternatively, Snorlax can use a spread of 184 HP / 72 Def / 252 SpD to avoid a 2HKO from Choice Specs Toxtricity's Boomburst after Stealth Rock.

Snorlax usually prefers to be on balanced and bulky offensive teams due to it checking major wallbreakers like Chandelure and its sweeping potential. Snorlax's weakness to Fighting-type attacks means it appreciates having Fairy-types teammates like Galarian Weezing, Gardevoir, and Togekiss. Galarian Weezing is particularly useful for switching into Guts Heracross, which can threaten to OHKO Snorlax even after a Curse. Cleric support from the likes of Sylveon and Umbreon is very helpful if Snorlax is forced out after using Rest. Snorlax enjoys having Toxic Spikes support from Dragalge and Galarian Weezing since it can pressure bulky Waters-types like Haze Milotic. Knock Off users like Incineroar and Obstagoon make great teammates because they are able to remove valuable items like Heavy-Duty Boots and Leftovers, making it easier for Snorlax to beat its checks such as Haze Milotic and Rhyperior. Snorlax likes to have Dark-type Pokemon such as Zarude and Drapion as teammates since they are able to check Ghost-types like Mimikyu and Doublade.

Crobat.overview: Crobat's great defensive typing provides it with many notable resistances and an immunity, which enables it to check premier threats such as Roserade, Heracross, and Golisopod. Its high Speed stat and use of Heavy-Duty Boots provide it with many opportunities to clear away entry hazards with Defog and pivot out of unfavourable matchups with U-turn. Crobat also has the potential to run stallbreaking sets that can bypass Pokemon like Cobalion, Milotic, and Sylveon. Crobat depends upon Heavy-Duty Boots for most of its defensive utility and is vulnerable to Knock Off from Golisopod and Heracross. Crobat also has a tough matchup against common Stealth Rock setters like Metagross, Stakataka, Steelix, and Necrozma, which prevent it from being able to consistently remove Stealth Rock. Crobat is very suspectible to Electric-types like Raikou, Xurkitree, and Toxtricity, and it faces stiff competition with Noivern, which can chip Steel-types like Steelix and Metagross with Flamethower and use Draco Meteor against prominent Electric-types such as Raikou, Xurkitree, and Toxtricity.
Crobat.comments:
Other Options

Super Fang turns Crobat into a stallbreaker that can wear down bulky Steel-types like Registeel and Metagross. Poison Fang can chip down Electric-types as well as Togekiss while having the possibility to weaken checks with Toxic. Nasty Plot can be run alongside special moves such as Sludge Bomb, Hurricane, Heat Wave, and Giga Drain to pressure checks to physical Crobat like Steelix and Metagross, but Crobat's Special Attack is very mediocre, leaving it outclassed by other special sweepers like Nasty Plot Togekiss and Reuniclus.

Checks and Counters

Super Effective Attackers: Common Electric- and Rock-types such as Raikou, Xurkitree, and Diancie resist Brave Bird and can easily KO Crobat with their STAB moves.

Faster Threats: Choice Scarf users such as Tyrantrum, Darmanitan, and Gardevoir can easily threaten Crobat by KOing it or pivoting as it's forced out.

Steel-types: Steel-types such as Metagross, Steelix, and Stakataka are only bothered by Super Fang and can use Crobat to set Stealth Rock up.

Bulky Setup Pokemon: Crobat struggles with breaking past bulky Pokemon like Reuniclus, RestTalk variants of Suicune, and Snorlax, though they donâ€™t appreciate being hit with Taunt.

sets.name: Pivot
sets.description:
U-turn capitalizes on Crobat's high Speed stat and keeps momentum for the team. Defog helps provide Crobat's team with entry hazard control. Alternatively, Taunt can be run to shut down defensive Pokemon like Body Press Registeel and Sylveon. Toxic can be used in conjunction with Taunt at the sacrifice of U-turn to wear down Pokemon like Milotic, Togekiss, and Umbreon.

Crobat fits mainly on bulky offense and balance teams, which benefit from its natural longevity from Heavy-Duty Boots and ability to keep up momentum for its team. Wallbreakers such as Chandelure, Heracross, and Toxtricity can take advantage of U-turn and force out many of Crobat's checks, including Metagross, Reuniclus, and Diancie. Ground-types such as Steelix and Flygon prevent Electric-types such as Raikou, and Xurkitree from constantly gaining momentum with Volt Switch, while Crobat can take care of common Grass- and Fighting-types like Roserade and Heracross. Crobat still struggles against bulky Steel-types like Seismic Toss Registeel, Steelix, and Metagross, so partners like Milotic and Gastrodon are beneficial. Knock Off absorbers like Cobalion help neuter Crobat's weakness to the move. Other pivots like Flygon, Raikou, Darmanitan, and Xurkitree can form a VoltTurn core to create momentum for Crobat's team and benefit from hazards being removed so they can constantly pivot around.

sets.name: Magic Bounce
sets.description:
Magic Bounce comes in handy for reflecting status moves such as Toxic and most importantly Stealth Rock from Pokemon such as Registeel and Steelix. Heat Wave allows Xatu to hit Steel-types like Klefki and Metagross. Giga Drain 2HKOes Seismitoad and chips away at Diancie. Teleport's negative priority allows Xatu to bring teammates in safely, but U-turn is an alternative move that makes Xatu a very reliable pivot by not making it take additional damage when pivoting. Rocky Helmet is a great item on Xatu because it helps to pressure Steel-type Stealth Rock setters such as Cobalion and Registeel. Heavy-Duty Boots is also a useful item because Xatu is not going to be able to deflect Stealth Rock from certain Stealth Rock setters, such as Diancie and Stakataka, therefore, Heavy-Duty Boots is needed to not get chipped by their entry hazards when pivoting. Finally, the 60 Speed EVs allow Xatu to outpace Jolly Bewear.

Due to the great roles that Xatu provides as a defensive pivot, it can fit on balance or bulky teams. Xatu likes to have offensive pivots as teammates, such as Zarude and Mienshao, which appreciate Magic Bounce keeping entry hazards off the field so they can be more reliable pivot's. Fairy-type Pokemon such as Togekiss, Sylveon, and Galarian Weezing can be very helpful teammates since they are able to check Dark-type Pokemon such as Obstagoon and Zarude. Meanwhile, specially defensive walls like Steelix and Porygon2 appreciate hazard prevention, since then they can check Electric-types such as Xurkitree and Thundurus more reliably.

sets.name: Rain Setter
sets.description:
Politoed enables a powerful but matchup-reliant archetype in rain due to being the only Drizzle Pokemon in the tier. However, outside of setting rain, Politoed is a generally underwhelming Pokemon that canâ€™t provide much help to rain teams itself and often becomes a momentum sink due to its passiveness. Encore allows it to deal with bulkier threats that would wall it otherwise and discourage Pokemon from setting up on it. Toxic can break down walls in tandem with Encore, particularly bulky Water-types that pose a threat to rain teams like Milotic. Hypnosis trades some effectiveness against passive builds for the potential to shut down common roadblocks to rain teams like Gastrodon and Assault Vest Reuniclus, and maintain utility against more offensive teams looking to take advantage of Politoedâ€™s passivity. Ice Beam chips Grass-types like Celebi, 3HKOes Dragalge, and OHKOes Noivern with the Special Attack investment. Perish Song forces bulky setup sweepers out, allowing Politoed to check Pokemon like Suicune, Snorlax, and Reuniclus. Finally, Rest allows Politoed to continue setting rain when severely weakened and in long matches against passive teams. Non-Ice Beam variants can invest the 76 Special Attack EVs into Defense, as they do nothing significant with Scald. 56 Speed EVs let Politoed outrun Alolan Marowak, but 92 Speed EVs can be ran for Milotic, which Encore + Toxic variants can beat.

Politoedâ€™s only niche is setting rain, so Pokemon that take advantage of it are necessary. Swift Swim Pokemon like Kingdra, Ludicolo, and Kabutops can offensively pressure the opponent and sweep once they are weakened. Electric-types of your own like Raikou and Heliolisk are able to run Thunder and Weather Ball as coverage and check Electric- or Water-types. Tornadus also enjoys fully accurate Hurricane and Weather Ball coverage. Toxicroak appreciates the Dry Skin recovery and can switch into Milotic with impunity. Steel-types like Metagross and Steelix can provide good defensive utility for rain teams and appreciate Fire-type moves being weakened under rain. Finally, entry hazard setters such as Klefki and Roserade can help pressure bulkier cores that threaten rain such as Suicune + Assault Vest Reuniclus, as well as synergizing with the surprising amount of switches Politoed can force from defensive Pokemon.

Umbreon.overview: Umbreon's high special bulk and defensive typing make it a great check for common special threats such as Necrozma, Chandelure, and Polteageist. Wish and Heal Bell enable it to stay healthy over the course of the battle and support its teammates. Foul Play allows Umbreon to better deal with various threats such as Golurk, Darmanitan, and Nasty Plot Celebi, while its ability Synchronize makes it difficult for Pokemon such as Raikou, Volcanion, and Milotic to weaken it with status moves. However, Umbreon's weaknesses to Fighting and Fairy leave it vulnerable to common threats such as Cobalion, Heracross, and Togekiss. In addition, its passive nature, increased by its two-turn recovery, makes it easy for many Pokemon such as Reuniclus, and the aforementioned Cobalion and Togekiss, to take advantage of it.
Umbreon.comments:
Other Options

Moonlight instead of either Protect, Wish, or Heal Bell gives Umbreon a one-turn recovery, but it does not have many PP and supporting teammates is one of the main reasons to use Umbreon. A physically defensive set can better check threats such as physical Necrozma, Flygon, and Golisopod. However, many teams prefer the specially defensive variant, since it counters more important Pokemon. 180 EVs can be invested into Speed to outspeed Adamant Golurk. However, this makes Umbreon worse against special attackers such Nidoqueen and Chandelure. Inner Focus with Toxic is an option to better deal with Togekiss, but it has less use outside of this matchup.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-types and Fighting-type Coverage: Cobalion is a huge threat to Umbreon, since it gets an Attack boost from Foul Play, is immune to Toxic, and threatens Umbreon with Close Combat. Bewear also takes huge advantage of Umbreon, but it dislikes Toxic. Heracross, Lucario, and Toxicroak take good damage from Foul Play but pressure Umbreon with their Fighting-type moves. Stakataka, Reuniclus, and Sharpedo often run Fighting-type coverage that can break through Umbreon.

Fairy-types: Barring sets with Toxic, Togekiss and Diancie easily set up on Umbreon. Klefki has nothing to fear from Umbreon, can set up Spikes freely, and pressures it with Toxic. Mimikyu can safely set up once due to Disguise and OHKO Umbreon with a boosted Play Rough. Although Gardevoir takes good damage from Foul Play, it 2HKOes Umbreon with Moonblast.

Bulky Setup Sweepers: Calm Mind Suicune, Reuniclus, and Curse Snorlax easily use Umbreon as setup fodder, since they take little from Foul Play and negate Toxic through Magic Guard, Rest, or Substitute.

Physical Attackers: Strong physical attackers such as Obstagoon and Darmanitan overwhelm or break through Umbreon, but most of them take a lot from Foul Play.

Taunt and Trick: Taunt and Trick users such as Noivern, Crobat, Gardevoir, and Chandelure restrict Umbreon to one move, allowing them to better deal with it.

Toxic-immune Pokemon: Pokemon that are immune to Toxic such as Registeel, Nidoqueen, and Steelix cripple Umbreon with their own Toxic and cannot be statused in return.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
Foul Play hits many physical attackers that try to take advantage of Umbreon such as Metagross, Golurk, and Flygon. Protect enables Umbreon to heal from Wish safely and scout Choice-locked Pokemon such as Gardevoir, Chandelure, and Heracross. If the team already has a cleric, Toxic is a good option over Heal Bell to punish common counters such as Togekiss, Incineroar, and Suicune. Since Umbreon is affected by every entry hazard, Heavy-Duty Boots gives it more switch-in opportunities and makes it less dependent on entry hazard control. Alternatively, Leftovers is a good choice for some passive recovery if the team has reliable entry hazard control.

Balance, semi-stall, and stall teams appreciate Umbreon's defensive qualities to check threatening Pokemon such as Polteageist, Chandelure, and Nidoqueen. Defensive Pokemon without reliable recovery such as Registeel, Stakataka, Bronzong, and Diancie appreciate Umbreon's Wish support. In return, they check Togekiss and either check troublesome Fairy-types or take the role of cleric to relieve Umbreon. Since Fighting-types such as Cobalion, Heracross, and Bewear heavily pressure Umbreon, checks to them such as Crobat, Galarian Weezing, and Dhelmise are very important. These Pokemon also give reliable entry hazard control if Umbreon runs Leftovers. On more defensive teams, Quagsire is a good choice to keep setup sweepers such as Reuniclus, Cobalion, and Suicune in check, while Choice Scarf Ditto is a reliable offensive check to them. Reuniclus and Necrozma are great setup sweepers on more semi-stalling teams and appreciate Umbreon's ability to check Ghost-types and keep them healthy with Heal Bell and Wish. Physical walls such as Gastrodon, Vileplume, and Galarian Weezing check troublesome physical threats such as Pangoro, Stakataka, and Sharpedo, which can overwhelm Umbreon.

Steelix.overview: Steelix's natural bulk, defensive typing, and multiple utility options make it an excellent Stealth Rock setter for balanced or bulky offensive teams. Its solid typing blocks Volt Switch from common Electric-types while also packing a Toxic immunity, qualities only it and Nidoqueen offer as Stealth Rock users. Additionally, it serves as a check to common threats like Xurkitree, Toxtricity, Registeel, and Metagross. However, some Electric- and Fairy-types, such as Raikou, Gardevoir, and Togekiss, commonly carry coverage moves that Steelix is vulnerable to. Steelix also struggles with common Water-types like Gastrodon, Milotic, and Volcanion, and its Grass neutrality makes it a Steel-type that cannot reliably check threats like Roserade.
Steelix.comments:
Other Options

Iron Defense + Body Press can handle threats like Curse Snorlax reliably. However, another move must be sacrificed for Iron Defense, and dropping Earthquake leaves Steelix susceptible to Electric-types. Dragon Tail or Roar could be thrown in for setup sweepers like Curse Gastrodon, Reuniclus, and Suicune. Unfortunately, the moves force Steelix to move last, so it can end up getting KOed by Scald or Focus Blast.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Milotic, Gastrodon, and Suicune barely take any damage from Steelix's moves and only worry about Toxic, which Suicune can cure with Rest.

Ground-types: Nidoqueen and Golurk offensively pressure Steelix. They don't want to be hit with Toxic, however.

Fighting-types: Pangoro and Heracross can pick off weakened Steelix with Close Combat.

Bulky Setup Sweepers: Magic Guard Reuniclus, Suicune, and Snorlax don't mind switching into Toxic and freely set up on Steelix.

Fire-types: Chandelure, Volcanion, and Darmanitan force Steelix out with ease. They need to beware of Earthquake from Sturdy variants, however.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
Heavy Slam reliably beats Sylveon, OHKOes Gardevoir, and 2HKOes Togekiss. Toxic puts common switch-ins to Steelix, like Milotic and Golirk, under pressure. The last moveslot is fairly flexible. Body Press, for example, allows Steelix to potentially 2HKO Umbreon and OHKO Obstagoon. Head Smash coupled with Rock Head can catch Crobat and Noivern off guard and force them to use Roost.

Since this set focuses on checking foes, setting up Stealth Rock, and providing Toxic support for balanced or bulky offensive teams, Steelix is forced out by numerous threats, including Ground-types like Golurk and Gastrodon. Because of this, teammates like Umbreon, Togekiss, and Milotic are appreciated. Milotic can switch into any of the Ground-types. Common Water-types like Milotic, Gastrodon, and Suicune force Steelix out or cripple it. Xurkitree, Raikou,and Roserade work as answers to them. Roserade can also provide Spikes support, put more pressure on Togekiss, and check Raikou, while Xurkitree can threaten other Ground-types with Energy Ball. Fire-types like Chandelure and Volcanion also offensively pressure Steelix, so partners like Incineroar and Noivern are greatly appreciated. Fighting-types like Heracross and Pangoro appreciate Steelix checking Fairy-types that they struggle with. Fairy-type partners like Sylveon and Galarian Weezing are appreciated, since Sylveon can provide Wish support as well as check threats like Toxtricity if need be, while Galarian Weezing works well as a switch-in to Fighting-types as well as Heracross and can provide Defog support. A teammate like Crobat or Darmanitan can scare off Grass-types like Celebi and Roserade, which Steelix is not a reliable switch-in or check to.

Heracross.overview: Guts Heracross stands as one of the most dangerous wallbreakers thanks to its freedom to choose between powerful attacks alongside its decent Speed tier, which lets it outspeed bulkier Pokemon and keep dangerous threats like Volcanion and Toxtricity in check. Heracross's typing enables it to take a hit from Zarude or Mienshao, giving it openings and expanding its defensive use. Meanwhile, Choice Scarf allows Heracross to act as a revenge killer and a potent cleaner, with Moxie allowing it to snowball after a KO. Despite Heracross's potency in wallbreaking, the Guts set cannot come onto the field easily by itself and is quickly worn down by entry hazards and its burn, mandating support and selective play. The Choice Scarf set requires the opposition to be heavily weakened to sweep and struggles with faster Choice Scarf users that can revenge kill it, especially if it lowers its defenses with Close Combat. Mienshao competes with it as a Choice Scarf Fighting-type, as it is faster, can pivot around with U-turn, and has Regenerator to combat chip damage, but Mienshao cannot snowball like Heracross can.
Heracross.comments:
Other Options

Choice Band is an alternative wallbreaking route that is able to stay healthy more easily while potentially bluffing a Choice Scarf set, but it is held back by its prediction-reliant nature in an environment with Pokemon like Togekiss, Crobat, and Alolan Marowak, which can sponge its STAB attacks.

Checks and Counters

Fairy-types: Even though Fairy-types like Togekiss, Sylveon, and Galarian Weezing are threatened by Facade from the Guts set, they can prove to be an annoyance if Heracross doesn't predict correctly. Galarian Weezing in particular does well if carrying Neutralizing Gas to negate Guts. Choice Scarf Heracross severely struggles with Fairy-types, as it has no direct workaround for most of them.

Faster Pokemon: Many threats such as Starmie, Obstagoon, Talonflame, and Mimikyu can outpace and threaten Guts Heracross. Choice Scarf Heracross can take a hit from certain Choice Scarf users, such as Zarude and Mienshao, but others like Darmanitan outspeed and KO it. If Heracross drops its defenses with Close Combat, more Pokemon are capable of revenge killing it even at high health.

sets.name: Guts Wallbreaker
sets.description: Megahorn OHKOes Psychic-types like Reuniclus, Cresselia, and Necrozma, while Swords Dance can ease prediction against Fairy-types and punish Protect users trying to rack up Flame Orb chip. Stone Edge can snipe Flying-types such as Crobat, Noivern, and Talonflame, which can otherwise take a hit and threaten Heracross out. Heracross puts immediate pressure on Steel-types and often zeroes in on Fairy-types such as Togekiss and Sylveon, which Zarude and Sharpedo can take advantage of. Heracross can break through most Pokemon by itself, but teammates like Starmie can prevent chip damage from entry hazards and pivots such as Thundurus and Darmanitan give Heracross openings to activate its Flame Orb, maximizing its chances to wallbreak. Certain Pokemon like Chandelure, Galarian Weezing, and Mimikyu can attempt to pivot around Heracross's attacks, racking up Flame Orb damage and punishing mispredictions, so having teammates like Darmanitan can help apply additional pressure on them.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Megahorn is a strong secondary STAB attack to clean with, but Spikes can be more effective against bulkier teams. Stone Edge allows Heracross to keep Crobat, Noivern, and Talonflame in check and potentially catch Togekiss attempting to switch in. The threat of a late-game sweep will require the opponent to preserve a set of Pokemon in order to handle any one move Heracross may try to clean with. Thus, partners like Obstagoon and Gardevoir can help wear down or threaten these Pokemon, which include Chandelure, Doublade, and Togekiss. Heracross's weakness to faster Choice Scarf users like Darmanitan can be mitigated by teammates like Rhyperior and Seismitoad, which can also set up Stealth Rock to chip away at the opposition. Running Spikes on Heracross not only helps its own sweeping efforts, but also assists other Pokemon like Stakataka and Necrozma, which benefit from Steel- and Water-types being worn down.

sets.name: Rain Sweeper
sets.description:
Kingdra's all-around good stats and access to Swift Swim make it an excellent choice on rain teams. Hurricane is used so that Kingdra can beat Grass-type Pokemon like Roserade without Draco Meteor Special Attack drops. Hydro Pump's main use over the more accurate Surf is to 2HKO even dedicated special walls like Registeel, Umbreon, and Assault Vest Reuniclus in rain; Surf is already powerful enough to OHKO most offensive Pokemon it hits neutrally. Flip Turn can be used instead to grab momentum off of Kingdra's checks and ease prediction for Choice Specs sets. Life Orb is the preferred item because it boosts power without locking Kingdra into one move; however, Choice Specs gives Kingdra the best chance to 2HKO bulky Water-types like Suicune and Milotic with Draco Meteor while also avoiding Life Orb's chip damage. Kingdra can opt for a Timid nature in order to outpace Choice Specs Gardevoir, which copies its Swift Swim with Trace, and improve its matchups against the likes of Togekiss and Chandelure out of rain.

Kingdra must always be supported by Drizzle from Politoed to activate Swift Swim. Without Drizzle support, Kingdra is outclassed by other offensive Water-type Pokemon like Starmie. Kingdra works best when used alongside other rain sweepers. Kabutops, Omastar, and Ludicolo can weaken bulky Water-type Pokemon like Milotic and Suicune. Toxicroak walls the aforementioned bulky Water-types and can also switch into First Impression attempts from Golisopod, making it an especially good Kingdra partner. In a similar vein, Tornadus benefits from Kingdra's Flip Turn to come in safely and break down bulky Water-type Pokemon.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description:
Porygon2 can function decently as a defensive pivot thanks to its great support movepool, Eviolite-boosted bulk, and amazing ability. Teleport allows Porygon2 to reliably get in powerful wallbreakers while sparing them from taking direct damage. Ice Beam is generally the preferred attacking move because it OHKOes Noivern and Flygon, while also 2HKOing Roserade and Golurk. Tri Attack is a decent alternative that does more to the likes of Xurkitree, Raikou, and Toxtricity. Toxic cripples the likes of Milotic, Volcanion, and Raikou, mitigating their long-term impact against Porygon2's teammates. Foul Play is an attacking option to hit Metagross and Alolan Marowak, while also letting Porygon2 check Polteageist much easier. A specially defensive spread allows Eviolite Porygon2 to blanket check many dangerous special attackers, such as Xurkitree, Toxtricity, and Roserade. Some Defense investment can be used to make Porygon2 a better pivot into the likes of Dhelmise and Flygon should its team need it. Trace allows Porygon2 to copy great abilities, like Regenerator from Reuniclus and Punk Rock from Toxtricity.

Porygon2 pairs very well with most offensive Pokemon, as it's able to absorb damage and switch them in safely with Teleport. Toxtricity, Darmanitan, Golurk, and Heracross are powerful wallbreakers that enjoy having Porygon2 to fall back on when they're forced out by certain special attackers, such as Noivern. A pivoting core can also be powerful, especially with the likes of Flygon, Incineroar, and Raikou, as it can keep Porygon2 in favorable situations. Incineroar deserves special mention because Intimidate helps it to stomach physical attacks for Porygon2, though it doesn't appreciate Knock Off removing its Heavy-Duty Boots. Togekiss and Galarian Weezing are great checks to Fighting-types while Porygon2 can easily handle most Toxtricity variants and other Electric types. Togekiss can even provide Defog and Heal Bell support, while Galarian Weezing can handle most Knock Off users. Powerful physical attackers such as Heracross, Darmanitan, Alolan Marowak, and Swords Dance Cobalion can take advantage of Porygon2's inability to generally threaten them. The aforementioned Togekiss and Galarian Weezing fare well against Heracross, while Suicune and Milotic can take on Darmanitan and Alolan Marowak. Healthy Noivern can switch directly into Cobalion and any Noivern can outspeed Heracross and Alolan-Marowak should Porygon2 predict their switch in with Teleport.

Raikou.overview: Raikou is a premier offensive pivot thanks to its high Speed forcing out other offensive staples like Cobalion, which gives it a clear advantage over fellow Electric-types Xurkitree and Toxtricity. Heavy-Duty Boots makes it difficult to wear down passively, letting it use Volt Switch with great freedom, and its useful coverage across Shadow Ball, Extrasensory, and Scald keeps many Pokemon from confidently switching into it. It can put that coverage to even greater use with its Calm Mind wallbreaking set. Its biggest problem is its glaring inability to hit Gastrodon and Flygon very hard; the best it can do is use Toxic or try to burn Flygon with Scald, so they hold it off well early-game. Its attacks are generally a bit weak, so it often relies on teammates to actually break through bulky Pokemon like Registeel and Assault Vest Reuniclus, and its defensive typing isn't good for much beyond switching into Togekiss and Xurkitree; this means it's hesitant to take strong attacks. The Calm Mind set sacrifices Volt Switch, making it a worse team player and harder to fit, and Xurkitree and Toxtricity are much better than pivot Raikou at breaking through cores by themselves.
Raikou.comments:
Other Options

Substitute + Calm Mind punishes passive defensive cores but lacks room for coverage. Aura Sphere on pivot Raikou puts the most pressure on Steel-types like Stakataka and Registeel; their low Speed and Volt Switch vulnerability make this less important on average. Weather Ball makes Raikou a much bigger threat on weather teams; hail gives it the excellent combination of Electric and Ice, rain gives it stronger Water-type coverage, and sun lets it hit Steel- and Grass-types with a single move.

Checks and Counters

Certain Ground-types: Ground-types that aren't weak to Scald are the safest early-game switch-ins to Raikou. Gastrodon has Recover and Storm Drain, making it near insurmountable for Raikou even when badly poisoned. Quagsire also has Recover while handling coverage moves well, and Choice Scarf Flygon can immediately force Raikou out but fears Scald burns.

Special Walls: Pokemon with a lot of special bulk, including Assault Vest Reuniclus, Registeel, Snorlax, and Umbreon, can take Raikou's attacks for a long time and immediately hinder it in return with Toxic or a strong attack. Pivot Raikou can just use Volt Switch the turn after they switch in, though.

Grass-types: If Raikou lacks Extrasensory, Roserade, and Vileplume are good switch-ins to it, and if it lacks Shadow Ball, Celebi, Dhelmise, and Decidueye handle its attacks well. Decidueye and Dhelmise want to avoid Scald burns, however.

Revenge Killers: Raikou's average bulk and lack of resistances make it easy for most faster Pokemon to take out once weakened. Physical Choice Scarf users such as Flygon and Heracross deal massive damage. Noivern and Salazzle are faster but struggle against Calm Mind boosts. Golisopod's First Impression also does the trick.

sets.name: Offensive Pivot
sets.description:
Volt Switch and Thunderbolt are staples for Electric-type pivots. Scald covers most Ground-types, threatening to burn Flygon and being super effective on Nidoqueen, Golurk, and Steelix. Toxic is the only way for Raikou to significantly impact Gastrodon switch-ins; if teammates can hit Gastrodon with Toxic or Knock Off, the last moveslot can be Extrasensory or Shadow Ball for specific Grass-type checks like Roserade and Celebi.

Raikou is a self-sufficient pivot that covers Togekiss and creates openings for all sorts of wallbreaker teammates. Grass-types like Roserade and Celebi cover Gastrodon, Raikou's biggest problems. A switch-in to Choice Scarf Flygon like Togekiss, Bronzong, or Vileplume will often help, though any Ground-immune Pokemon goes a long way in limiting it. Psychic-types like Reuniclus and Necrozma can take advantage of non-Extrasensory Raikou's Poison-type switch-ins, Roserade and Toxtricity.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description:
Calm Mind Raikou can surprise those expecting the pivot set and break through weakened cores. Scald covers most Ground-types, threatening to burn Flygon and being super effective on Nidoqueen, Golurk, and Steelix. Shadow Ball covers Celebi, which is near impossible to break through otherwise, while Aura Sphere pressures Registeel and Umbreon, resilient special walls. Leftovers creates more chances to boost, but Heavy-Duty Boots can save Raikou more HP short term if your team lacks entry hazard control and fears Stealth Rock + Spikes.

Calm Mind Raikou needs more support than its pivot set given its lack of Volt Switch and preference to avoid early damage. Physical wallbreakers like Heracross and Swords Dance Incineroar pressure special walls, and Grass-types cover Gastrodon. Steel-types like Metagross and Stakataka work as extra answers to Flying-types and can use Toxic on Gastrodon switching in. Entry hazard removers like Crobat, Starmie, and Dhelmise help Leftovers sets accrue enough HP to be worthwhile.

Entei.overview: Choice Band Entei is a solid wallbreaker that punishes conventional Fire-type answers such as Flygon, Diancie, and Suicune with a burn from Sacred Fire. Furthermore, Entei can act as a revenge killer with Extreme Speed, letting it pick off many dangerous sweepers like Cloyster, Flygon, and Sharpedo. Entei also has a great Speed tier for a wallbreaker and outspeeds key offensive threats such as Mimikyu, Obstagoon, and Xurkitree. The team compression provided by being both a wallbreaker and revenge killer, as well as sporting great natural bulk and a key Speed tier, makes it particularly sought after on sun teams. Under sun, Entei's counterplay dwindles, as once hard stops like Gastrodon, Quagsire, and Snorlax have a high chance of getting 2HKOed by sun-boosted Flare Blitz after Stealth Rock and burn. However, Entei's Stealth Rock weakness severely limits it, especially on sun teams, which generally lacks thorough entry hazard removal. Outside of sun teams, Entei faces far harsher competition from other wallbreakers, especially Darmanitan, which can afford to run Heavy-Duty Boots, is about as strong as Choice Band Entei, and can keep up momentum with U-turn.
Entei.comments:
Other Options

Heavy-Duty Boots may seem tempting, but the loss of power compared to Choice Band is rarely worth it and makes it even harder to justify using Entei over Darmanitan. Similar to Suicune, Entei can attempt to run a Calm Mind + Substitute set, but such a set can't touch Chandelure, has few switch-in opportunities, retains Entei's Stealth Rock weakness, and still struggles with Water-types, especially Haze Milotic.

Checks and Counters

Bulky Water-types: Bulky Water-types such as Milotic, Gastrodon, and Quagsire can switch into any attack and heal off burn damage with Recover; however, the latter two need to watch out if they're burned, as they have a high chance of getting 2HKOed by sun-boosted Flare Blitz after Stealth Rock. Suicune can also take any hit from Entei, but it doesn't enjoy a potential burn.

Entry Hazards: In general, Entei is at the full mercy of entry hazards, especially Stealth Rock and Spikes, as it cannot afford to use Heavy-Duty Boots.

Faster Threats: Entei will rarely be at full health, which leaves it vulnerable to be revenge killed by faster threats like Noivern, Starmie, and Raikou.

Snorlax: While not the most common, Snorlax completely counters Entei thanks to Thick Fat and Rest. However, sun-boosted Flare Blitz has a near-guaranteed chance to 2HKO Snorlax after Stealth Rock.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Extreme Speed is what truly differentiates Entei from the other Fire-types. Stone Edge hits Fire-types such as Incineroar, Volcanion, and Chandelure, as well as Noivern. Flare Blitz is much stronger than Sacred Fire and is a must on sun teams, as it has a good chance to 2HKO a burned Gastrodon or Quagsire after Stealth Rock in the sun. On non-sun teams, Iron Head is a viable option to OHKO Diancie; while it despises a burn from Sacred Fire, Diancie can easily switch into Entei and set Stealth Rock. Toxic is also an option to cripple bulky Water-types such as Milotic, Gastrodon, and Suicune, but with Sacred Fire's 50% burn rate, it can become useless if not played carefully. Inner Focus blocks Intimidate from Incineroar, so it can't switch into Entei's Fire-type attacks in sun.

The playstyle that takes full advantage of Entei's strengths and plays to its full potential are sun teams. Torkoal sets Stealth Rock, sun with Drought, and can remove entry hazards with Rapid Spin. On sun teams, Entei can either work as the team's sole wallbreaker or be run alongside others like Charizard and Heliolisk and act primarily as a revenge killer. Entei lures bulky Water-types such as Gastrodon and Milotic and forces them to use Recover, which can be exploited by Shiftry to get an opportunity to use Growth or a huge hit off. Choice Scarf Gardevoir provides Healing Wish support to heal up Entei after taking many rounds of Stealth Rock damage or attacks from the likes of Togekiss, Mimikyu, and Crobat. On non-sun teams, Entei needs more support to break past bulky Water-types. Assault Vest Reuniclus's Future Sight and lures to Water-types like mixed Metagross and offensive Starmie are effective ways of weakening or getting rid of Gastrodon and Milotic. Pokemon such as Raikou, Flygon, and Stakataka can cripple Gastrodon, Suicune, and Quagsire with Toxic, which greatly aids Entei. Entry hazard removal from Pokemon such as Crobat, Flygon, and Starmie give Entei as many opportunities to wallbreak as possible. They also can provide free switches for Entei with either U-turn or Teleport.

sets.name: Substitute + Calm Mind
sets.description:
Subtitute + Calm Mind Suicune relies on Pressure to wage a war of attrition on a number of Pokemon that can wall it such as Seismitoad, Gastrodon, and Mantine. Calm Mind makes it very hard for special attackers to break Suicune's Substitute and makes Scald much harder to switch into. Substitute provides Suicune with a way to protect itself from status effects, which will cripple sets lacking Rest, and is especially effective for PP stalling Pokemon unable to break its substitute in one hit. Note that Suicune must still be cautious not to switch into status moves like Toxic and Thunder Wave from the likes of Registeel, Togekiss, and Klefki. Protect enables Suicune to scout Choice item users, stall out low PP moves, and gain additional Leftovers recovery. Ice Beam can be used to hit the likes of Zarude and Seismitoad after boosting, which are otherwise major threats. Roar is another option that allows Suicune to phaze out other setup sweepers and rack up entry hazard damage. The EV spread allows Suicune to outpace base 80 Speed Pokemon like Chandelure and Togekiss, while giving it an 81% chance that Seismitoad's Earthquake will not break its Substitute. An alternative spread with maximum Speed will allow Suicune to Speed tie with Heracross, but lowers its chances of its Substitute surviving Seismitoad's Earthquake to about 56%. This set lacks recovery other than Leftovers, so Suicune must be careful not to take Knock Off from Pokemon like Incineroar and Obstagoon without a Substitute up. Suicune must also be careful not to get hit by Trick from the likes of Darmanitan and Gardevoir, as it completely cripples this set.

Suicune's natural bulk and typing make it a great choice for teams looking to check threats like Darmanitan, Alolan Marowak, and Metagross. Suicune's best check is Zarude, which can use Jungle Healing to remove any Scald burns and threaten Suicune with Power Whip. Therefore, it pairs well with Zarude checks like Cobalion, Galarian Weezing, and Togekiss. Cobalion has the added bonus of being an excellent Knock Off absorber thanks to Justified, while Galarian Weezing and Togekiss check other threats to Suicune like certain Guts Fighting-types such as Machamp and Heracross. The aforementioned Guts users, along with Obstagoon, pose a notable threat to Suicune because they are powerful enough to threaten Suicune and unafraid of burns from Scald. Sylveon or Togekiss notably can provide Heal Bell support to remedy this set's weakness to status effects. Suicune is also threatened by Electric-types like Xurkitree, Toxtricity, and Raikou, so it should be used alongside Electric-type checks such as Roserade, Assault Vest Reuniclus, Zarude, and Vileplume. Finally, Suicune lacking Roar is unable to beat certain Calm Mind sweepers with Psyshock like Reuniclus and Sigilyph, so it is wise to pair it with checks to them like Obstagoon and Chandelure.

sets.name: RestTalk
sets.description:
This Suicune set is capable of sweeping given the right conditions. Rest allows this set to be extremely resilient to status and provides it with reliable recovery. Sleep Talk prevents Suicune from being passive while using Rest. Roar can be used over Sleep Talk in order to more reliably defeat other Calm Mind sweepers like Reuniclus and rack up entry hazard damage. This set runs enough Speed EVs to outpace Adamant Golurk and Jolly Alolan Marowak, then invests the rest in Defense and HP to be as hard to break through as possible. This, along with reliable recovery in Rest, makes it a much better answer to the likes of Darmanitan, Sharpedo, Cobalion, and Stakataka.

Rest renders this set much less vulnerable to status effects and Knock Off, but it still has one major nemesis in the meta: Zarude. Zarude can use Jungle Healing to easily remove Scald burns, and this set lacks the safety net of Substitute to allow moves like Ice Beam to be effective. Checks to Zarude include Pokemon like Cobalion, Incineroar, Crobat, Noivern, and Togekiss. This set has difficulty setting up Calm Mind against offensive Electric-types like Xurkitree, Raikou, Heliolisk, and Toxtricity, so checks like Roserade, Zarude, Celebi, and Porgyon2 work well with it. Heliolisk has the added danger of Dry Skin causing Water-type moves to heal it, so Suicune must be played particularly carefully against it. If running Roar, Suicune can phaze foes into Spikes provided by Roserade, making it a particularly notable partner.

Celebi.overview: The following analysis is outdated and is currently being revamped. Information contained in the analysis may be misinformative in regards to the current SS RU metagame.

sets.name: Utility
sets.description:
Celebi serves as a decent utility option for balanced teams thanks to its natural bulk, reliable recovery, ability in Natural Cure, and Speed tier. It also serves as a reliable switch-in to Xurkitree and Raikou. Thunder Wave lets it paralyze common threats like Noivern and Necrozma. U-turn allows Celebi to pivot on common switch-ins to it like Togekiss and Metagross to give its team momentum. Psychic hits Pokemon that otherwise freely switch into Celebi like Noivern and Roserade. Grass Knot hits Ground-type threats like Steelix harder so Celebi can spread paralysis more effectively and beats Water-types like Milotic.

U-turn from threats like Mienshao and Darmanitan easily forces Celebi out. Therefore, teammates like Galarian Weezing, Togekiss, and Cobalion are appreciated to absorb it. These same teammates can come in on Golisopod, which can OHKO Celebi. Wallbreaking teammates like Chandelure, Mienshao, and Guts Heracross can take advantage of Celebi pivoting on Steel-types and special walls like Metagross, Stakataka, and Umbreon. A partner like Milotic to check Fire-types like Chandelure, Volcanion, and Darmanitan takes pressure off of Celebi.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Choice Scarf Celebi has a niche on balance and bulky offense teams thanks to its Speed tier, utility moves in U-turn and Trick, and ability in Natural Cure. It's also able to check Electric-types like Raikou and Xurkitree with little to no issue. Trick cripples common switch-ins to Celebi like Inciniroar, Togekiss, and Registeel. U-turn lets Celebi pivot on switch-ins like Incineroar and Metagross, and gives its team momentum.

Despite being one of the faster Choice Scarf users, Celebi is vulnerable to Choice Scarf Mienshao. Partners like Togekiss and Galarian Weezing can take any move that either threat has to offer. Additionally, both can provide Defog support, since Celebi is susceptible to entry hazards as it pivots. A partner like Heracross or Swords Dance Cobalion that can take advantage of Celebi's U-turn is appreciated. Threats like Incineroar, Metagross, and Snorlax can take advantage of Celebi being locked into an attack. Milotic, Rhyperior, and the aforementioned Cobalion make good teammates to handle such foes. These same teammates also appreciate Celebi coming in to absorb Scald.

sets.name: Belly Drum
sets.description:
Linoone is a fearsome sweeper with Belly Drum alongside STAB Extreme Speed, but it is held back by its difficulty setting up and the prevalence of Cobalion. Stomping Tantrum allows Linoone to heavily damage Steel-types like Registeel, Steelix, and Stakataka, but Cobalion will outspeed and KO Linoone before it can use it. Seed Bomb hits bulky Water-type Pokemon like Gastrodon, Milotic, and Suicune for greater damage than Extreme Speed, and also 2HKOes Quagsire, which can otherwise wall Linoone easily by ignoring its boosts with Unaware. Alternatively, Throat Chop hits Pokemon like Dhelmise, Cresselia, and Reuniclus while potentially letting Linoone set up on Sylveon and Toxitricity. Play Rough is another option that gives Linoone a better matchup against Bewear and Umbreon. Linoone should customize its moveset with these moves based on its team's needs. Linoone runs enough Speed to outpace Chandelure.

Linoone's all-or-nothing nature and lack of defensive utility make it work best on hyper offense teams. Cobalion is Linoone's most widely used and consistent answer, easily surviving a +6 Extreme Speed and OHKOing back with Close Combat, so Linoone should be paired with Cobalion checks like Crobat, Chandelure, and Golisopod. Linoone can set up much more easily with dual screens support from Pokemon like Xatu and Klefki. Cloyster is a good partner that wears down Cobalion, and it can potentially lure and heavily damage it with Hydro Pump. Steelix and Cobalion are also worn down by Spikes support from Klefki and Golisopod. Finally, Linoone appreciates Memento support from teammates like Gardevoir and Galarian Weezing.

Ludicolo.overview: Ludicolo is a niche pick on rain teams in RU as a Swift Swim sweeper due to its ability to threaten annoying bulky Water-types such as Gastrodon, Suicune, and Milotic with Giga Drain. It also has perfect coverage to hit the tier for at least neutral damage, making it sometimes difficult to deal with it. However, Ludicolo is very dependent on rain to make up for its mediocre offensive presence; otherwise, it is very easy to check and revenge kill. Even under rain, Ludicolo still struggles against specially defensive Pokemon that are not weak to its STAB moves, such as Assault Vest Reuniclus, Umbreon, and Porygon2. Many Pokemon can also revenge kill Ludicolo such as First Impression Golisopod, Trace Gardevoir, and Choice Scarf Flygon, even under rain. Ludicolo is also difficult to fit on many rain teams, as they prefer other Swift Swim sweepers like Kingdra and Kabutops or teammates such as Tornadus and Noivern that can handle problematic foes like Toxicroak and bulky Grass-types.
Ludicolo.comments:
Other Options

Knock Off can be used instead of Protect to punish common switch-ins such as Porygon2, Assault Vest Reuniclus, and Umbreon by removing their key items. Leaf Storm allows Ludicolo to OHKO Suicune and potentially OHKO Milotic.

Checks and Counters

Special Defensive Pokemon: Porygon2 and Umbreon deal with Ludicolo by stalling out rain turns and Hydro Pump PP with recovery moves or, in Umbreon's case, the combination of Wish and Protect. Registeel and Bronzong can be 2HKOed by Weather Ball under rain after some chip damage, but they can stall out some rain turns with Protect and cripple Ludicolo with Toxic. Once rain is over, these Pokemon deal with Ludicolo more easily.

Faster Threats and Priority Users: Trace Gardevoir and Choice Scarf Flygon outspeed and revenge kill Ludicolo, even in rain. Golisopod OHKOes Ludicolo immediately with First Impression, while other priority users such as Lucario and Entei revenge kill Ludicolo once it is weakened enough. Klefki can be OHKOed by Ludicolo's Weather Ball under rain after some chip damage; however, it can keep Ludicolo in check with Prankster Thunder Wave.

Toxicroak: Toxicroak is a huge threat to rain teams due to its typing, Dry Skin, and Sucker Punch. It is also a threat to Ludicolo, since it takes both of Ludicolo's STAB moves easily and can either OHKO it with Gunk Shot or revenge kill with Sucker Punch. However, Toxicroak is quite frail and can be 2HKOed by Ice Beam.

Opposing Weather: Opposing weather setters can be extremely annoying for Ludicolo, since it is dependent on rain. Torkoal replaces the rain with its sun but must watch out for a potential Hydro Pump.

sets.name: Swift Swim
sets.description:
Under rain, Weather Ball is Ludicolo's most reliable and best STAB move. Hydro Pump, on the other hand, lets Ludicolo better deal with specially defensive Pokemon such as Umbreon and Porygon2 and also gives it a strong Water-type STAB move outside of rain. Giga Drain deals with bulky Water-types and negates passive damage like recoil from Life Orb. Ice Beam hits Grass- and Dragon-types such as Celebi, Roserade, and Noivern super effectively, which resist both of its STAB moves. Protect avoids First Impression from Golisopod, which is a common threat to rain teams, and also helps to scout for Choice-locked Pokemon such as Gardevoir. 196 Speed EVs with a Timid nature can be used to allow Ludicolo to be faster than Choice Scarf Flygon alongside 60 HP EVs to take opposing attacks a little better.

Since Ludicolo's only niche is on rain teams, Politoed is a necessary teammate to set rain. Swift Swim sweepers like Kingdra and Kabutops pile on more rain-boosted offense and appreciate Ludicolo's ability to take on bulky Water-types like Gastrodon and Milotic. Flying-types like Tornadus and Noivern help rain teams deal with Toxicroak and bulky Grass-types like Celebi and Dhelmise. Klefki can act as a secondary rain setter, set Spikes, and check Gardevoir.

sets.name: Sun Sweeper
sets.description:
Shiftry is the most viable Chlorophyll sweeper in the tier, being able to muscle past common checks to Grass-types and sweep with its near perfect coverage at +2. Solar Blade helps Shiftry wallbreak more effectively if run on full sun teams, although Leaf Blade is more consistent once sun runs out and against other weather teams. Knock Off provides wide neutral coverage, hitting Grass-resistant Pokemon such as Noivern, Metagross, and Chandelure. Low Kick hits most Steel-types harder and has a chance to 2HKO Incineroar. Heat Wave is boosted by sun, hitting Fairy-types like Galarian Weezing and Togekiss neutrally as well as OHKOing Chople Berry Cobalion and Heracross, but it misses out on Incineroar and hits most Low Kick targets such as Registeel for slightly lower damage. Protect is an option that significantly improves Shiftry's matchup against teams that rely on Golisopod to check sun, although it sacrifices a valuable move.

Shiftry only fits on teams with sun setters, so Torkoal is a mandatory partner. Torkoal provides the necessary sun, while also bringing Stealth Rock and setup opportunities with Yawn. Darmanitan can also take advantage of sun, breaking down the opposing team's defensive structure and bring Shiftry into Water-types with U-turn. Heliolisk can similarly wallbreak under sun and pivot out of Ground-types. Entry hazard removal is necessary, as sun teams will often have multiple hazard-weak Pokemon, and Shiftry can get chipped into KO range of priority moves easily. Defog Noivern is a good utility option for this role, while Xatu can bounce back hazards and pivot with Teleport.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Gardevoir's good coverage, high Special Attack, and acceptable Speed tier makes it a good Choice Specs user in RU. Focus Blast provides crucial coverage for Steel-types that aren't hit neutrally by Gardevoir's STAB moves, such as Registeel, Stakataka, and Steelix. Shadow Ball hits Assault Vest Reuniclus, Metagross, and Doublade, having near-perfect coverage alongside its STAB attacks and Focus Blast. Mystical Fire hits Klefki harder and is more accurate, but the power loss is very notable, failing to 2HKO Registeel and OHKO Steelix after Sturdy is broken. Psyshock can be used to hit Snorlax hard with a STAB move, but it is overall weaker, especially against physically bulky threats such as Cobalion and Volcanion. Trace is the preferred ability to grab useful abilities from opposing Pokemon, such as Regenerator from Mienshao, Punk Rock from Toxtricity, and Water Absorb Volcanion.

Choice Specs Gardevoir's wallbreaking prowess can be taken advantage of by a myriad of Pokemon that thrive late-game. This includes Pokemon such as Xurkitree and Choice Scarf Heracross. The latter two are capable of bashing through Steel-types, which is a good trait considering Gardevoir can sometimes struggle to break through them alone. Gardevoir is also quite frail, and it can struggle to properly switch into battle sometimes. Pivots such as Darmanitan, Rotom-Mow, and Crobat are good teammates that are capable of bringing Gardevoir in safely. The latter two are capable of teaming up with Gardevoir to eventually beat down Steel-types that don't have a reliable recovery option, such as Metagross, Registeel, and Stakataka, while Darmanitan can just outright force them out. Spikes setters like Klefki, Roserade, and Golisopod are another very useful way to pile on the damage to Steel-types. Knock Off support from the likes of Golisopod and Incineroar can also be useful, as it removes Assault Vest from Reuniclus, Eviolite from Porygon2, Leftovers from Steel-types like Registeel and Metagross, and Heavy-Duty Boots from Togekiss and Incineroar. This allows Gardevoir to make more progress against these threats, as the former two will take more damage from Gardevoir and the latter two will be more vulnerable to cumulative chip damage, therefore making it easier for Gardevoir to break past them.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Choice Scarf Gardevoir's main niche comes from its access to useful utility moves in Trick and Healing Wish, which give it a notable advantage over other Choice Scarf users in the tier like Heracross, Xurkitree, and Darmanitan. Trick allows Gardevoir to cripple defensive Steel-types such as Registeel, Steelix, and Stakataka. Healing Wish can be especially useful when paired with a strong, frail wallbreaker or a defensive teammate that lacks a consistent form of recovery. Memento can also be useful to give a teammate such as Barbaracle, Cloyster, or Linoone a setup opportunity. Teleport is also very good when paired with a wallbreaker that threatens Steel-types, as Gardevoir has a tendency to lure them in. Gardevoir can also use Mystical Fire over a utility move in order to hit Metagross, Steelix, and Doublade, but these utility moves give Choice Scarf Gardevoir its niche.
