Klefki switches into and sets up Spikes or dual screens on Pokemon that Necrozma forces in such as Zarude, Registeel, and Assault Vest Reuniclus. Togekiss, Mimikyu, and Sharpedo can set up on or threaten Necrozma's common switch-ins such as Assault Vest Reuniclus, Incineroar, and Umbreon. Necrozma can weaken Steel-types for Pokemon such as Cloyster, Mimikyu, and Linoone to clean up. Polteageist struggles greatly with Dark-types, so it appreciates Necrozma weakening Zarude and Incineroar.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description:
After Dragon Dance, Necrozma is faster than the entire unboosted metagame but misses out on every common Choice Scarf user. Earthquake tears through Incineroar and Steel-types such as Metagross, Stakataka, and Registeel. X-Scissor OHKOes the omnipresent Zarude and hits Psychic-types such as Reuniclus and the rare Cresselia and Celebi. With Lum Berry, Necrozma can set up on defensive Pokemon such as Togekiss, Seismitoad, and Milotic without fearing status. Prism Armor lets Necrozma take most super effective attacks with ease, so Weakness Policy can be used instead to gain even further boosts.

Dragon Dance Necrozma fits best on hyper offense, as it takes care of roadblocks like Cobalion and Zarude, which answer common team members such as Cloyster and Polteageist. Dual screens support from Klefki, Xatu, and Vanilluxe let Necrozma use Dragon Dance multiple times, make it harder to revenge kill, and create more chances to activate Weakness Policy. Klefki also provides Spikes to wear down bulky Steel-types like Steelix and Metagross. Misty Terrain from Galarian Weezing means Necrozma can run Weakness Policy without missing Lum Berry. Other setup sweepers like Cloyster, Barbaracle, and Polteageist can set up early and soften up the opposing team so Necrozma can clean up or vice versa. Necrozma can weaken bulky Steel-types for teammates such as Mimikyu, Linoone, and, on teams with Vanilluxe, Arctozolt.

Stakataka.overview: Stakataka is one of the better defensive Pokemon in the RU metagame due to its incredible bulk, defensive typing, and multiple utility move options. It functions primarily as a Stealth Rock user for bulky offensive and balanced teams. Stakataka's main advantage over its Stealth Rock-setting competition in Metagross, Registeel, and Cobalion is its typing. Its combination of Fire neutrality and Flying, Fairy, and Psychic resistances means it checks many common threats utilizing Fire-type coverage like Gardevoir, specially offensive Necrozma, and Noivern in addition to Salazzle and Chandelure. Its quadruple Normal resistance makes it one of the tier's better ways to take Toxtricity's Boomburst as well. Unfortunately, since Stakataka's the slowest Pokemon in the tier, it's usually getting hit first and worn down easily, and it is forced to make predictions even when other defensive Pokemon are switching in. Its 4x Ground and Fighting weaknesses mean it finds itself offensively pressured a lot.
Stakataka.comments:
Other Options

Choice Band can be used to punch holes in opposing teams and catch the opponent off guard. However, due to Stakataka's slow Speed and Choice lock, it can easily be set up on. Shuca Berry or Chople Berry on the defensive set allows Stakataka to tank an attack from threats like Aerodactyl, Flygon, and Metagross or Heracross, Mienshao, and Cobalion. Unfortunately, Stakataka sorely misses passive recovery, and taking a super effective attack will likely leave it with little HP remaining anyway. An offensive Trick Room set can work as a cleaner, although there are better sweepers that dont have to rely on Trick Room.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-types and Fighting-type Coverage: Due to Stakataka's 4x weakness to Fighting, threats like Heracross, Pangoro, and Cobalion are just a few Pokemon that send it running. None of them want to switch into it, however. Body Press Registeel and Aura Sphere Raikou are just a couple of threats with coverage to also exploit this weakness.

Ground-types and Ground-type Coverage: Pokemon like Golurk, Nidoqueen, and Gastrodon have little to fear from Stakataka and force it out. Metagross, Aerodactyl, and even opposing Stakataka are just a few Pokemon that carry Earthquake as a coverage move and can severely hurt Stakataka.

Bulky Water-types: Milotic, Suicune, and Gastrodon can come in safely on Stakataka and heal any damage.

sets.name: Defensive Stealth Rock
sets.description:
Body Press hits Steel-types the hardest and takes advantage of Defense boosts from Beast Boost. Toxic cripples switch-ins to Stakataka like Gastrodon and Milotic. Stone Edge, however, nails Chandelure, Volcanion, and Golisopod. Leftovers gives Stakataka some staying power over the course of a match, especially against Air Slash flinches from Togekiss. 0 Speed IVs and a Sassy nature make Gyro Ball as strong as possible.

Stakataka's typing gives it some more weaknesses than other Steel-types; its Water weakness makes it worse against threats like Sharpedo and Suicune, while its gnarly quadruple weaknesses to Ground and Fighting ruin its ability to check threats like Steelix, Metagross, Raikou, and Celebi. Teams wielding Stakataka must cover its glaring weaknesses with the rest of their defensive core. Water- and Grass-types such as Volcanion, Suicune, Dhelmise, and Celebi can take on threatening Water-types for Stakataka. Certain Grass-types can also take on threatening Ground-types such as Flygon and Golurk, as can Bug-types like Heracross and Golisopod. Options like Togekiss and Crobat are solid checks to Fighting-types like Heracross and Pangoro. Sylveon also fits the bill, and it can use Wish to keep Stakataka healthy throughout the match. These Pokemon also appreciate Stakataka's defensive profile. Grass-type teammates like Roserade appreciate Stakataka being a decent switch-in to Fire-types and stonewalling most of the tier's Flying-types. Stakataka's sturdy resistance to Toxtricity's Boomburst and ability to deal with Xurkitree to an extent can give Ground-types like Gastrodon some breathing room. Stakataka fails to keep Stealth Rock up against Defog Volcanion and Rapid Spin Starmie. Electric-types such as Raikou and Xurkitree can force those two out consistently, and Knock Off users like Incineroar, Golisopod, and Salazzle can remove Volcanion's Heavy-Duty Boots, making it easier to wear down.

sets.name: Offensive Pivot
sets.description:
With higher Speed than the likes of Noivern, Crobat, and Aerodactyl, high base Attack, good coverage, and access to Flip Turn, Barraskewda is a good option as an offensive pivot. However, due to its frailty and vulnerability to most revenge killers, Barraskewda faces difficulty sweeping teams. Ice Fang covers Noivern and Grass-types such as Roserade and Dhelmise. Psychic Fangs also KOes Roserade, hits Vileplume and Crobat harder, and removes screens. Close Combat's raw power helps Barraskewda deal with Cobalion more easily and weaken Gastrodon, Seismitoad, and Volcanion, which can block Flip Turn with their abilities. Double-Edge can be used over Ice Fang and Psychic Fangs to hit Golisopod the hardest, though its recoil is inconvenient. Heavy-Duty Boots gives Barraskewda more opportunities to switch in and pressure the opposition. An Adamant nature can be used on rain teams, where Barraskewda can also use Choice Band to maximize its damage and act more as a wallbreaker.

Barraskewda has a hard time dealing with bulky Water-types such as Gastrodon, so Grass-types such as Roserade are good teammates. However, it is also annoyed by Volcanion, which Noivern and Assault Vest Reuniclus can answer. Noivern can bring Barraskewda in with U-turn, and Reuniclus can help Barraskewda wear down walls with Future Sight and Knock Off. Fire-type wallbreakers such as Salazzle, Chandelure, and Darmanitan can help Barraskewda pressure Water-types and appreciate Barraskewda using Flip Turn as Grass-types switch in. Other pivots such as Raikou, Noivern, and Incineroar are good options for teammates. Incineroar, in particular, has Knock Off and Toxic to help Barraskewda weaken its checks. Barraskewda also loves Golisopod's and Roserade's Spikes support along with Knock Off users such as Incineroar and Assault Vest Reuniclus.

Toxtricity.overview: Choice Specs Toxtricity is one of RU's strongest sources of immediate damage thanks to its Punk Rock-boosted Boomburst, which has very few consistent switch-ins. Pokemon with the typing or special bulk to take Boomburst, like Stakataka and Porygon2, are vulnerable to Toxtricity's coverage or lose momentum to Volt Switch. Though slow, Toxtricity poses a massive early-game threat to offensive teams, as staples like Noivern cannot immediately OHKO it and fear getting OHKOed in return. Its resistances let it even switch into and punish Cobalion, Roserade, and Raikou once or twice, especially if they go for utility moves. Once Toxtricity has taken some damage, however, it becomes much less of a threat, as its low Speed and bulk will make it easy for many Pokemon to pick off. Its vulnerability to Stealth Rock and Spikes worsens this issue, especially in a metagame full of pivots using Heavy-Duty Boots, which incentivizes conventional offensive teams to forgo entry hazard removal. It faces competition from RU's other top Electric-types, Raikou and Xurkitree; the former's naturally high Speed lets it remain a threat to offense all game long, while the latter can use Choice Scarf to similarly threaten offense or Heavy-Duty Boots to wallbreak like Toxtricity without fearing entry hazards. Both Electric-types are always faster than offensive Togekiss, which can overcome weakened Toxtricity with Air Slash flinches.
Toxtricity.comments:
Other Options

A Shift Gear set using Boomburst, Overdrive, Drain Punch, and Life Orb or Throat Spray with maximum Special Attack and Speed investment and a Mild or Hasty nature can be a nasty surprise sweeper that beats and sets up on Porygon2. With so many other sweepers and Choice Scarf users available, including Sharpedo, Cloyster, Mimikyu, Xurkitree, and Heracross, dedicating Toxtricity to the role is usually unnecessary and a waste of its power.

Checks and Counters

Entry Hazards and Offensive Pressure: Offensive teams often won't have a solid switch-in to Toxtricity beyond a one-time check like Steelix; they bank on trading damage with it or wearing it down with Stealth Rock and Spikes until it's in KO range of faster Pokemon. Toxtricity's unremarkable bulk means this won't take long. Most aggressive teams will also give Toxtricity very few opportunities to directly switch in.

Ghost-types: The presence of a Ghost-type forces Toxtricity to think twice about spamming Boomburst, limiting how much damage it can get out of its attack opportunities. Golurk and Lightning Rod Alolan Marowak are even immune to Electric, meaning Toxtricity has to risk using the generally mediocre Snarl or Sludge Bomb. Colbur Berry Dhelmise can take a hit from Toxtricity pretty well. Ghost-types generally work well with Ground-types by maximizing the number of predictions Toxtricity has to make.

Porygon2: Punk Rock halves damage taken from sound-based moves, making Trace Porygon2 a very reliable switch-in to Toxtricity, albeit one wide open to Volt Switch.

Specially Bulky Pokemon: Snorlax and Registeel can stand up to Toxtricity's attacks for a while, though they lose momentum to Volt Switch and are easily pressured. Diancie and Stakataka can switch into Boomburst but hate Electric-type attacks. Steelix and Assault Vest Reuniclus can switch into Boomburst once and threaten to KO in return.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Punk Rock Toxtricity's Boomburst has obscene power and coverage, OHKOing or 2HKOing most Pokemon and even 3HKOing Steelix. Overdrive is a consistent Electric-type attack that punishes Boomburst switch-ins like Stakataka and Diancie. Volt Switch lets Toxtricity bring a threatening teammate in against relatively consistent checks like Porygon2 and Registeel. Snarl catches the occasional Golurk along with OHKOing Alolan Marowak. Sludge Bomb is an alternative that can poison bulky switch-ins, 2HKOes Alolan Marowak, and OHKOes Trace Gardevoir. Toxtricity's Speed tier isn't crowded, so it can get away with a Modest nature. Running a Timid nature is advantageous against other Toxtricity, though it makes Pokemon harder to OHKO with Boomburst.

Proactive teams using offensive pivots like Noivern and Volt Switch Cobalion are best at giving Toxtricity chances to freely attack and compensating for its poor Speed. Flygon and Incineroar are U-turn users that pivot on switch-ins like Togekiss and Galarian Weezing, which healthy Toxtricity is then free to exploit. They form a VoltTurn core with Toxtricity as well, giving defensive teams a miserable time. Other Fighting-types like Heracross punish bulky Normal- and Steel-types for switching into Boomburst. Toxtricity is a very self-sufficient attacker once it's made it into the battle, so its team doesn't need to give it much specific support; just have a plan for when common threats switch in to revenge kill it.

Polteageist.overview: Polteageist is an excellent Shell Smash sweeper due to its useful offensive typing and good stats, and the combination of Cursed Body and Strength Sap allows it to stall out, disable, and break through the majority of its checks such as Obstagoon and Snorlax. Polteageist is a great pick on hyper offense, where it can be supported properly and form wallbreaking cores with Pokemon like Lucario. However, Polteageist's shallow offensive movepool means it must pick whether it gets walled by either Dark-types or Normal-types, and it cannot hope to outlast Pokemon like Umbreon. It also relies on fishing for Cursed Body to get past its checks, and status effects can limit its longevity to the point where it isn't feasible to do so.
Polteageist.comments:
Other Options

Polteageist can run Stored Power + Giga Drain to hit both Dark- and Normal-types on the same set, although it doesn't really have the space for it. Weak Armor and Focus Sash might appear enticing, but losing out on Cursed Body and White Herb makes it less effective at outlasting its checks.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types: Due to its lack of coverage, Dark-types are the biggest roadblocks preventing a Polteageist sweep. Umbreon completely blanks Polteageist and can use the opportunity to use Wish or Heal Bell. Similarly, Stored Power variants are unable to touch Obstagoon. Incineroar beats Polteageist unless severely weakened, although Toxic variants may lose with Misty Terrain support. A healthy Pangoro can break through Polteageist's Strength Sap, although Giga Drain can dent it.

Status: Toxic puts Polteageist on a timer, preventing it from spamming Strength Sap and fishing for Cursed Body, while paralysis leaves it vulnerable to faster revenge killers.

Normal-types: Without Stored Power, Polteageist can be threatened by Normal-types such as Snorlax and Porygon2, which can stall it out through Rest or Toxic. Choice Band Bewear and Choice Specs Indeedee can also check Polteageist if healthy. However, all of them can lose if sufficiently weakened.

Priority: Certain types of priority can cut a Polteageist sweep short, such as Shadow Sneak from Doublade, Mimikyu, and Decidueye, Thunder Wave from Klefki, and, if sufficiently weakened, First Impression from Golisopod and Flygon.

sets.name: Shell Smash
sets.description:
Polteageist stalls out most physical attackers with Strength Sap and can disable their moves with Cursed Body. Giga Drain allows Polteageist to beat Obstagoon after a Strength Sap, prevents Milotic from using Haze, and provides useful recovery. Alternatively, Stored Power beats Normal-type Pokemon such as Porygon2 and Snorlax and gives a stronger neutral hit, although it makes Polteageist much more vulnerable to Dark-types, particularly Obstagoon. White Herb eases setting up and crucially lowers Knock Off damage after it's been used. The EV spread outspeeds Choice Scarf Flygon after boosting and allows Polteageist to take a Knock Off from Obstagoon at -1.

Pokemon commonly found on hyper offense such as Mimikyu, Necrozma, and Lucario complement Polteageist well, either helping break down its checks like Porygon2 or taking advantage of it weakening its checks itself like Swords Dance Incineroar to clean. Fighting-types like Lucario and Cobalion can deal with Normal- and Dark-types like Umbreon and Snorlax. Offensive support can greatly facilitate a Polteageist sweep. For example, Indeedee's Psychic Terrain can block priority and strengthen Polteageist's Stored Power. Alternatively, Misty Terrain from Galarian Weezing neutralizes Pokemon like Toxic Incineroar, Klefki, and Noivern. Spikes from Froslass or Focus Sash Heracross can help to weaken checks like Obstagoon.

sets.name: Guts Wallbreaker
sets.description:
Thanks to its Guts ability, potent STAB moves, and decent Speed tier, Obstagoon proves itself to be a powerful wallbreaker in the RU metagame. Close Combat allows it to nail Rock- and Steel-types like Stakataka, non-Chople Berry Cobalion, and Registeel. Switcheroo lets Obstagoon cripple opposing switch-ins, like Diancie and Steelix, while Obstruct allows it to either ensure Flame Orb burns it or scout moves from Choice item threats like Heracross and Gardevoir. Obstruct also helps Obstagoon beat slower bulky threats like Doublade and Incineroar due to the Defense drop it provides.

Neutralizing Gas Galarian Weezing negates Obstagoon's Guts boost and can easily take multiple attacks from it. Therefore, teammates to deal with Galarian Weezing such as Chandelure, Necrozma, and Toxtricity are greatly appreciated. VoltTurn partners such as Raikou, Noivern, and Flygon can safely bring Obstagoon in against favorable matchups. Fighting-types pose a problem to Obstagoon given its 4x weakness to Fighting; Fairy- or Psychic-type partners like Togekiss, Sylveon, and Gardevoir offensively pressure said Fighting-types, while Obstagoon wears down Steel-types for them with Close Combat. Naturally faster threats like Raikou and Noivern easily force out Obstagoon; defensive switch-ins like the aforementioned Togekiss, Milotic, and Registeel can come in on these faster threats and eat up their moves.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Indeedee-M's primary role in the RU tier is as a wallbreaker that is capable of pushing past many neutrally hit, specially bulky targets. Mystical Fire hammers the likes of Steelix and Metagross for super effective damage while also lowering the Special Attack of switch-ins like Assault Vest Reuniclus, thus making it easier for Indeedee-M's teammates to switch into them. Shadow Ball can be used for a stronger hit against Assault Vest Reuniclus, while maintaining coverage against Metagross and Bronzong, but in turn misses out certain Steel-types like Registeel and Klefki. Hyper Voice is an alternative STAB move that gives Indeedee-M a more reliable move to lock into if Dark-types like Incineroar or Obstagoon are present, notably being Indeedee-M's strongest option against the former. Trick can cripple special walls like Umbreon and Registeel to make it even easier for Indeedee-M's team to deal with them, but losing its Choice Specs makes Indeedee-M much less effective at breaking down defensive cores. Dazzling Gleam OHKOes Obstagoon and can 2HKO Umbreon after some prior damage.

Indeedee-M appreciates teammates that can handle extremely bulky Psychic-type answers, particularly Umbreon and Registeel. Fighting-types such as Cobalion and Heracross can handle these threats and clean up late-game once Indeedee-M has broken down an opponent's defensive core. Spikes support from Roserade and Klefki is also appreciated, as it can allow Indeedee-M to push past Umbreon on its own with Dazzling Gleam while also exploiting Registeel's lack of reliable recovery on repeated switch-ins. Faster threats, such as Crobat, Cobalion, and Choice Scarf Heracross have problems switching in but can easily revenge kill Indeedee-M. Pokemon like Metagross and Nidoqueen can check these threats and set Stealth Rock. Sharpedo and Cloyster are powerful late-game cleaners that benefit from Psychic Terrain protecting them from dangerous priority moves. Pokemon such as Milotic and Flygon can utilize pivot moves to effectively switch in Indeedee-M on favorable matchups.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Indeedee-M's good Speed and Psychic Surge-boosted Expanding Force allows it to revenge kill numerous RU staples, such as Noivern, Raikou, and Cobalion, with a Choice Scarf equipped. Mystical Fire 2HKOes bulkless Metagross and can make it easier for teammates to switch into Psychic-resistant Pokemon, such as Reuniclus. Hyper Voice 2HKOes Obstagoon after entry hazard damage and does more to Psychic-types like Necrozma and Starmie. Trick is essential for crippling special walls like Registeel, Umbreon, and Porygon2.

Indeedee-M has a very hard time with special walls, particularly Umbreon, Registeel, and Porygon2. This makes Obstagoon, Cobalion, and Heracross great teammates, as they can easily remove these special walls and weaken most defensive Pokemon in general with their powerful attacks. Flygon is a troublesome faster Choice Scarf user that can revenge kill Indeedee-M, thus making Togekiss and Vileplume good teammate options. Togekiss can utilize a Nasty Plot set to weaken or outright remove Steel-types for Indeedee-M, while Vileplume can potentially punish U-turns with Effect Spore. Spikes from Roserade and Klefki is also appreciated, as all of the special walls Indeedee-M struggles with are vulnerable to the entry hazard. Late-game cleaners, such as Sharpedo and Cloyster, that appreciate Psychic Terrain protecting them from opposing priority moves are good choices to use with Indeedee-M as well.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description:
Dragon Dance Regidrago is a solid late-game sweeper once key roadblocks are removed. Regidrago's average-to-good bulk and Dragon typing lend it many setup opportunities against bulky Water-types such as Milotic and Suicune, but also against passive walls like Registeel. However, even after a boost, Regidrago is slower than every common Choice Scarf user. The Speed raise from Scale Shot can prevent Choice Scarf users from revenge killing Regidrago after setup, but it's inconsistent due to its variability in power. After a Dragon Dance, Thunder Fang 2HKOes even bulky Togekiss. Substitute helps Regidrago set up by blocking Scald burns and Toxic. The passive recovery from Leftovers means Regidrago can use Substitute many more times throughout a battle. An Adamant nature is preferable to ensure the 2HKO on Togekiss with Thunder Fang after a Dragon Dance.

Try as it might, Regidrago can't break through Steelix, Galarian Weezing, Diancie, and Doublade. Luckily, wallbreakers like Starmie and Golurk can pick up the slack and blow past each one with relative ease. Fighting-types such as Guts Heracross, Bewear, and Pangoro can also overwhelm Diancie and Galarian Weezing while breaking Steelix and Doublade. Crobat, Darmanitan, and Incineroar can safely switch Regidrago into the battlefield with U-turn. Darmanitan and Incineroar synergize particularly well with Regidrago, as they can bring it in against bulky Water-types for a setup opportunity. Disguised as Regidrago, Zoroark can lure Galarian Weezing, Sylveon, Steelix, and Doublade with coverage moves in Extrasensory, Sludge Bomb, and Flamethrower. Dragon Dance Regidrago fits well on dual screens hyper offense teams, as it can get multiple boosts with ease thanks to its titanic bulk under dual screens. One notable Pokemon commonly seen on dual screens hyper offense is Cloyster; after a Shell Smash, it can OHKO both Doublade and Galarian Weezing with Hydro Pump. Other hyper offense staples like Necrozma and Mimikyu can help with breaking bulky Steel-types.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Choice Band Dragon's Maw-boosted Outrage is a sight to behold, but in a tier infested with Fairy- and Steel-types, Regidrago finds its effectiveness limited. Nevertheless, with good team support, Regidrago is a force to be reckoned with. Scale Shot is decently strong and doesn't lock Regidrago in like Outrage does. The Speed raise also makes it harder to revenge kill with faster threats like Noivern and Starmie. Hammer Arm is Regidrago's best move to hit Diancie as well as Steel-types such as Steelix and Registeel. Thunder Fang is a near-guaranteed 2HKO on max HP Togekiss. Explosion is an alternative over either Outrage or Scale Shot, as it opens the door for Regidrago's teammates by either severely weakening or outright KOing Togekiss, Sylveon, or Galarian Weezing. Crunch is also an option to hit Doublade and 2HKO Metagross and Bronzong but has no other relevant targets.

Regidrago can do next to nothing against Sylveon, Galarian Weezing, and Doublade. Toxtricity is noteworthy for dealing with the mentioned Pokemon and weakening Steelix, which repeatedly switches in on Regidrago otherwise. Fighting- and Dark-types like Heracross and Sharpedo can pair with Regidrago to overwhelm shared checks, such as Fairy-types. Regidrago can also lure and severely weaken Fairy-types with Explosion so its Fighting- and Dark-type teammate can clean up afterward. Zoroark can disguise itself as Regidrago with Illusion to lure and surprise Fairy-types with a super effective Sludge Bomb. Pivots like Raikou, Milotic, and Darmanitan are excellent for safely bringing Regidrago onto the field. Darmanitan and other Fire-types like Volcanion and Incineroar are grateful for Regidrago breaking bulky Water-types such as Milotic and Gastrodon. Spikes support from Roserade and Klefki helps whittle down sturdy Steel-types like Steelix, Metagross, and Doublade.
